instruction: How did the researchers validate the accuracy of the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method in estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with changing SM-CRM?
Output: The researchers validated the accuracy of the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method in estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with changing SM-CRM through both laboratory-based and field-based experiments, as well as using Sentinel-2 broadband remote-sensing images. These experiments involved obtaining a spectral dataset from a field-based experiment with a field spectrometer and a laboratory-based simulation that included different soil types, crop residue types, and varying SM-CRM. The researchers trained a random forest (RF) model called the broadband crop-residue index from random forest (CRRF) using the spectral features of crop residue and soil as input and a moisture-resistant hyperspectral index as the target. The effects of moisture on crop residue and soil were minimized using the broadband CRRF. The CRRF-NDVI triangular space method was then used to estimate and map CRC, FVC, and BS. By comparing the results obtained from the proposed method with the laboratory-based and field-based experiments, as well as the Sentinel-2 remote-sensing images, the researchers were able to validate the accuracy of the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method in estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with changing SM-CRM.

instruction: Can the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with significant changes in SM-CRM?
Output: Yes, the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with significant changes in SM-CRM. This is because the CRRF model, which is trained using broadband remote sensing angle indices and a moisture-resistant hyperspectral index, minimizes the effects of moisture on crop residue and soil. By using the CRRF-NDVI triangular space method, the spatial locations of mixed remote sensing pixels in the triangular space can distinguish CRC, FVC, and BS. The method has been validated through laboratory- and field-based experiments as well as Sentinel-2 broadband remote-sensing images, indicating its potential for accurately estimating and mapping CRC, FVC, and BS in croplands with significant changes in SM-CRM.
